reels.caption: √à tornato dove il ghiaccio sembrava eterno. Ma non l‚Äôha pi√π trovato. Nel cuore dell‚ÄôIslanda, @alexbellini_alone ha visto con i propri occhi cosa significa il cambiamento climatico. E ha scelto di raccontarlo. Il 29 luglio, alla Fortezza del Priamar, chiude Clima in Proiezione in dialogo con Edoardo Cremonese, climatologo di @fondazionecima e con il Presidente Luca Ferraris. Un confronto sul senso del limite, tra scienza ed esplorazione. Perch√© esplorare oggi non √® superare confini. √à ascoltarli...

‚ÄúIl problema dell‚Äôambiente √® un problema di relazioni‚Äù con se stessi, con gli altri, con il pianeta. Una riflessione potente di @alexbellini_alone sul palco del Green&Blue Festival 2025, dove ha portato il suo punto di vista da esploratore e divulgatore. Esperienze estreme, viaggi oltre i confini e un impegno costante per raccontare la fragilit√† della Terra üå± Il Green&Blue Festival continua anche il 6 e 7 Giugno dal Museo Scienza e Tecnologia di Milano.
reels.transcript: The problem of the environment, the problem of pollution, the problem of plastic is not an environmental problem, and it's not even a human problem. It's a problem of relationship, the relationship of men with themselves, men with other men, men with the environment. if I could, with a magic wand, find something, I'd to discover people who are willing to restore some relationships. starting from the easiest things, the relationship with things, rethink our relationship with things, maybe something. . . Even simply with plastic things, ? From there.

reels.caption: Il Canada va ancora a fuoco. Oltre 220 roghi attivi, su un‚Äôarea di 20mila ettari e noi, a 7.000 chilometri di distanza, dall‚Äôaltra parte dell‚Äôoceano, possiamo vedere chiaramente quanto non esista davvero un ‚Äúaltrove‚Äù abbastanza lontano da non essere toccato da eventi naturali di tale portata. Cosa ci insegna questa ennesima tragedia umana e ambientale?
reels.transcript: Maybe it has happened to you too in these days to look up at the sky and notice something strange, an unusual yellowish color, a milky color that veils the sun and darkens the blue. From Turin, where I am now, for the Film Festival, Cinema Ambiente, up to the entire Padana plain, this phenomenon has become at least since mid-May, more and more evident. but you asked yourself where all this comes from? Well, the answer is surprising. What we see above our heads is smoke. Smoke coming from over 7, 000 km away. Smoke from fires that are devastating the forests of Canada on the other side of the Atlantic. More than 200 active fires, over 30, 000 evacuated people and millions of people forced to stay at home due to the unbreathable air. This is an environmental tragedy, a climatic tragedy, a human tragedy. If it weren't for the destruction it brings with it, it would be almost a fascinating phenomenon. A clear and unequivocal signal. The planet is talking to us again. It is trying to remind us of a simple truth, but too often forgotten. What happens in a remote place, affects us too, in one way or another. There is no other way. The air has no borders, the climate has no borders, the earth is a single living system. When a part of the planet goes on fire, Nobody really stays safe.

reels.caption: "It‚Äôs clear that we don‚Äôt live surrounded by many small oceans, but within one vast ocean system." @alexbellini_alone Explorer
reels.transcript: What I the most is that, when you're traveling by sea, you're far from everyone and everything, but for some strange, mysterious reason, you feel connected to everything. You feel connected to people who are no longer there, you feel connected to people you no longer see, you feel connected to people you've never seen, but who somehow become central in your existence. In the sea, it is clear, evident, how we do not live immersed in many small oceans, but in a great ocean system that allows the movement, the flow of currents, of the sea. And this thing often comes to mind because even in the most desperate moments, I looked up at the sky and felt connected with everything else. the rest, but above all I felt connected to something bigger than me.

reels.caption: Continua l‚Äôavventura festivaliera per il nostro documentario #beyond . Domani 1 luglio sar√† proiettato al @nuovimondifestival , nel Distretto culturale MontagnaFutura, nei comuni di Rittana, Valloriate, Roccasparvera e Maiola (CN). Programma e biglietti su @nuovimondifestival.
reels.transcript: I'm Alex Bellini. I'm an explorer. In 2017 I crossed the biggest glacier in Europe, the Vatnaj√∂kull, in Iceland. Never before have I feared to lose my life. Never before have I gone close. In 2025, eight years later, I felt the need to return to those places, to seek answers and maybe to go beyond.

reels.caption: Se il mental training √® un tuo interesse, ho creato un canale Telegram fatto apposta per te. Trovi il link in bio üëã
reels.transcript: Hello friends, those who have known me for a long time know how deep my passion for mental preparation and sports performance is. It was born in 2011 when I ran through the United States supported by an extraordinary team of professionals. And it grew over time, first as an athlete and then as a consultant. What fascinates me about this discipline is the same impulse that pushes me towards exploration, that is, the curiosity to discover what is inside and what is beyond our limits. Yet here on my channels, I want to leave space for the other two interests, that is, exploration and disclosure. I have always struggled to share this part of me, this interest of mine. But over time I realized that we don't necessarily have to sacrifice a part to make room for the rest. on the advice of some friends I decided to open a new space all dedicated to mental preparation a telegram channel where I will share tips, techniques and exercises to improve in the sport but perhaps even more important to grow as a person if you are interested in this topic and want to deepen or simply receive some useful stimulus I invite you to subscribe, you can find the link in bio noi ci vediamo presto, ciao!

reels.caption: √à sinonimo di forza interiore, tenacia e capacit√† di rialzarsi. √à una delle qualit√† che pi√π ammiriamo negli atleti di successo, ma sappiamo davvero cos‚Äô√® la resilienza? E soprattutto: sappiamo come svilupparla e applicarla nella nostra pratica sportiva e nella vita di tutti i giorni? Per scoprirlo vi invito a partecipare al webinar ‚ÄúResilienza: dalla teoria alla pratica‚Äù, in programma il 29 luglio alle 16:30. Un‚Äôora per trasformare concetti astratti in strumenti concreti. Per partecipare iscrivi...
reels.transcript: It is synonymous with inner strength, tenacity, recovery and grit. It is one of the qualities that fascinates us the most, and perhaps also the one we envy the most among high-level athletes. I'm obviously talking about resilience, that characteristic that allows us to respond in a healthy and effective way to adversity. We hear about it a lot, yet it is not yet clear to everyone whether it is a natural quality or something that we can train, in which factors weaken it and which instead reinforce it. If you also want to discover how to bring it into your daily life, then I invite you to participate in the free webinar Resilienza, from theory to practice, scheduled for July 29th, at 4. 30 pm and reserved for only those who subscribe to the Telegram channel. An hour together to understand, to train and to grow that silent strength that allows us to bend without breaking. To participate, I invite you to follow the link you find in bio. Ci aspetto! Ciao!

reels.caption: Io e @francescaurso_ stiamo dando vita a un progetto straordinario, innovativo e stimolante, pensato per gli studenti delle classi IV delle scuole superiori della Valtellina. Si chiama ‚ÄúI Custodi dell‚ÄôAcqua‚Äù e guider√† i ragazzi in un percorso formativo e trasformativo, con l‚Äôobiettivo di renderli protagonisti attivi, capaci di immaginare soluzioni per proteggere, rigenerare e gestire in modo pi√π lungimirante le risorse idriche del territorio. E questo √® solo l‚Äôinizio‚Ä¶ ne parleremo ancora. üí™ #icu...
reels.transcript: There is an invisible thread that connects the snowy peaks of the Valtellina to the fruit trees of the Fondovalle. A thread that ties the streams of the high mountains to the large ponds or the hands of a farmer to the thirst of the cities. And this thread is water. Water is not just an element, but it is the symbol of our deep and indissoluble bond with nature. These days I am here in Valtellina, in my beloved Valtellina, to start an educational project called I Custodi dell'Acqua. designed together with Francesca and promoted by the province of Sondrio, in which we want to talk about this, about giving value to water and how we can take care of it. Starting from the school year 2025-2026, we will involve about 1, 500 students from higher schools. We will meet women and men who every day commit themselves to preserving water and we will listen to their stories to understand how we too can become agents of change. The goal is to transform young people into explorers of their territory. In protagonists of a new water culture, able to build bridges between a fragmented present and a future that requires awareness, vision and responsibility. I'll tell you more in the next few weeks, but now, excuse me, I'm going to meet a new water guardian and let you imagine who this new guardian will be. Consider that I am in one of the most beautiful vineyards here in the Valtellina, in the heretical side of our valley. All right, see you next time!

reels.caption: L‚Äôaltra sera ho partecipato alla premiere del documentario Reef Builders, che mostra le operazioni di ripristino di alcune barriere coralline degradate in giro per il mondo. Qui ti do 3 buone ragioni per vederlo in TV stasera.
reels.transcript: But as I told you in the last stories, the other day Milan participated in the premiere of the documentary Reef Builders which shows the restoration operations of some coral barriers degraded around the world. , in a first phase they build small metallic structures in the shape of a sea star. Then they attach small pieces of coral to this structure and deposit everything on the bottom of the ocean. And then nature does its job. The first aspect that struck me a lot is that now every time man tries to interact with nature, in the best cases the effect is negative and when it is really bad, the effect is catastrophic. These volunteers once in a while show that human interaction with nature can still produce regenerative effects. The second aspect that surprised me is the speed with which corals react. In Indonesia, for example, one of the areas under the post-recovery zone, the speed of regeneration is surprising. Within a few days from the deposit on the bottom of these metal structures, the coral filaments begin to grow and a year later the barrier is barren that you no longer see the metal structures. Of course, not everywhere the project has brought the expected successes. In Kenya, for example, the project has had some difficulties, but it is only about finding the species of coral more resilient to the high temperatures of that specific stretch of sea. And watching the film, I felt a great desire to immerse myself and restore the corals to me too. The third aspect is that the film manages to make us understand with great clarity how closely our life is linked to coral reefs and nature in general, which are custodians of unique biodiversity in the world. protecting and restoring them not only can contribute to the absorption of CO2, helping to counter climate change, but also has important economic implications. Just think that about half of global wealth depends on nature. I gave you at least three good reasons to watch the Reef Builders documentary. You can find it on Amazon Prime today. I'll put the link in bio.

reels.caption: Tra pochi mesi, i leader mondiali si incontreranno a Ginevra per l‚Äôultimo round di negoziati sul Trattato Globale contro l‚ÄôInquinamento da Plastica. Per questo abbiamo voluto rendere visibile il problema e coinvolgere, in modo creativo, un pubblico nuovo in un appello concreto: mettere un limite alla produzione globale di plastica. Se ti stai chiedendo cosa puoi fare, inizia da qui: condividi questo reel. #Eurovision2025Basel #UnitedByMusic #ESC2025 #EurovisionSongContest #ESC #Eurovision #Globa...
reels.transcript: We are on the Rhine, one of the most polluted rivers in the world, or at least in Europe. I'm sailing on board this raft, which I nicknamed Contiki, in memory of the famous Contiki of the Pacific Ocean, to raise awareness among people about the impact of plastic, in particular microplastics, on aquatic ecosystems, but clearly also on the health of humans, and to encourage and encourage political decision-makers will meet in Geneva in just over a month for the Global Plastic Treaty. Finally, once and for all, to put a maximum roof on the annual production of plastic. This is a symbolic journey to bring to light the problem of plastic, because many plastic fragments go deep, they disappear from the eyes and consciousness of people. On this bamboo and plastic bottle rack, we really want to bring to light, show, make visible this problem that now afflicts all ecosystems. Ciao!

reels.caption: √à uscita una nuova edizione del libro Il Piccolo Principe (@mgmt_edizioni). Felice di aver curato la prefazione di questo piccolo libro a cui sono legato in modo particolare.

Con tutto ci√≤ che succede nel mondo, fermarsi a guardare questa biglia di roccia e acqua sembra una lusso per pochi o una distrazione da cose pi√π urgenti. La crisi climatica, essendo non solo una crisi ecologica o tecnica, ma anche e sopratutto una crisi di visione, di valori, di narrazione impone una riflessione possibile solo se ci liberiamo per un attimo dalla forza di gravit√† che ci tiene ancorati con i piedi a terra e agisce sui nostri schemi mentali. In fondo, ci√≤ che facciamo al pianeta √®...

reels.caption: Dal 5 al 7 giugno a Milano si terr√† l‚Äôedizione 2025 del Green&Blue Festival. Siete tutti invitati. In bio e nelle stories trovate il link per registrarvi.
reels.transcript: 420, the current concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere, or 0, the emissions of global greenhouse gases by 2050. Or 30, the percentage of oceans and land that will be protected by 2030. Hi, I'm Alex Bellini, and no, I'm not giving you the numbers. I'm inviting you to the Green and Blue Festival, the Republic Festival that will take place from June 5 to 7 in Milan at the Science and Technology Museum. This year the festival aims to identify to identify the key numbers to photograph the current state of health of the Earth and at the same time set the goals necessary to guarantee a future for its inhabitants. In addition to me there will be exceptional guests and I hope to meet my childhood myth, the explorer and aviator Bertrand Piccard. The festival, as always, is free, but I recommend you register. , before leaving, here in the comments, write to me what, in your opinion, is the number that identifies the current state of health of the Earth. Ciao!

reels.caption: Guarda il film completo al link in bio
reels.transcript: The meaning of this adventure in Alaska is not to do a sprint race The meaning of this project in Alaska is to tell how Alaska changes when the climate changes Alaska is the American state that is warming up faster than any other and for this reason it is a sentry of climate change the famous canary in the mine that warned us in advance about the global effects of warming up A few days later we reach the village of Una Laklit and the school's president, who hosts us, tells me about the current conditions in her community.

reels.caption: A vent‚Äôanni dall‚Äôuscita in Italia, Neri Pozza celebra questo capolavoro con una giornata interamente dedicata al libro. Sabato 12 aprile, in oltre 50 librerie in tutta Italia si organizzano letture dei brani pi√π belli di Shantaram. E dalle 18.30, a Milano, presso la libreria Il Trittico in via San Vittore ‚Äî e anche in diretta online ‚Äî parteciper√≤ a un incontro speciale del Club Neri Pozza, insieme alla casa editrice e ad altri ospiti, per raccontarti cosa Shantaram ha significato per me. Ci vedi...
reels.transcript: In 2005, the publisher Neri Pozza published a monumental novel, the story of an Australian evasive, a man on the run, not only by law but also by himself and his adventurous life in India. The protagonist is really a bit of a good guy, but the humanity and humility with which he tells his story make you fan for him from the first pages. If I had to use an extreme synthesis, I would say that this book is a hymn to human imperfection, to our ability to make mistakes and then to transform ourselves, the ability to get lost and finally to find ourselves. You surely understand which book I'm talking about. Well, I'm clearly talking about Shantaram. Now you understand why I called it monumental. This book is much more than a novel. It's a real adventure that takes you and takes you far away, in the heart of Bombay of the 80s, making you live and breathe those chaotic dusty streets that only exist in India, where absurd things happen. At the end of the reading I felt I was at the end of a long journey, not only because it accompanied me for several months, in fact I have the habit of reading more books at the same time, but also because, any real journey, it gives you back your life, different from how you started. It is certainly among the books I loved the most. And if I had to choose a theme among the many who cross these almost 1200 pages, certainly the personal transformation of Lynn, therefore the protagonist, is what struck me the most. his transition from a criminal life to an altruistic commitment in the communities of Indian barracks embodies a path of redemption that speaks to the need of all of us to give a deep meaning to our existence.

reels.caption: La scorsa settimana sono stato a Parigi per partecipare alla prima Giornata Internazionale per la Protezione dei Ghiacciai, un‚Äôoccasione per accendere i riflettori sugli impatti economici, sociali e ambientali dei cambiamenti che stanno trasformando la criosfera. Qual √® la misura del successo di queste giornate internazionali?
reels.transcript: Last week I was in Paris to participate in the first International Day for the Protection of the Ice Age, an opportunity to turn on the reflectors on the economic, social and environmental impacts of the changes that are transforming the cryosphere. The cryosphere is the set of all the surfaces of the Earth where water is in solid form, from the ice age to polar caps, to permafrost and sea ice. It plays a crucial role in the energy balance of the planet, reflecting solar radiation, regulating temperatures and influencing ocean currents. But today this immense ice reserve is melting at an alarming rate, with consequences that go beyond the Alpine Vettes or the polar regions. In Paris I also had the pleasure of meeting some of the people who have influenced my exploratory path the most, the Norwegian Borg√•sland, one of the most prolific polar explorers. , yes, the Italian minister was also waiting, but no one saw him. Strange, considering that Italy is among the most affected European countries by the loss of ice. It has already had to redraw part of the Alpine border with Switzerland because of the ice retreat and risks losing the Marmolada by 2040. The meeting was also an opportunity to reiterate that the next decade will be the decade of action for the sciences of the cryosphere. An initiative aimed at stimulating scientific cooperation and strengthen efforts for sustainable development. But coming back home I asked myself, what will have to happen until in 10 years we can say that this awareness campaign has been successful? The answer is in a number, 430. 47. It is the current concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. If in 10 years this figure will increase, it doesn't matter how many political commitments will be made, how many conferences will be organized, or how many ambitious plans will be announced. It will mean that we are failing. And we must admit that days these have been nothing more than communication exercises, Good for a few titles, but unable to really change reality.

reels.caption: Oggi, nella prima Giornata Internazionale della Preservazione dei Ghiacciai, e ad un anno esatto dalla fine del nostro viaggio in Alaska sono felicissimo di presentarvi il video che documenta (in modo imperfetto, ma onesto) quei 37 giorni di avventura. reels.caption: Nel 2017 ho attraversato il Vatnaj√∂kull, in Islanda. √à stata, senza dubbio, l‚Äôesperienza in cui sono andato pi√π vicino a perdere la vita. A gennaio 2025 ho scelto di tornare in quei luoghi per provare a rispondere alla domanda perch√© l‚Äôessere umano esplora? Da quest‚Äôidea ne √® nata una riflessione sul senso dell‚Äôesplorazione e sul concetto di limite, ma anche sulla rinuncia, sulla perseveranza e sulla curiosit√† che ci muove. Anteprima nazionale in programma al @trentofilmfestival il giorno 26 apr...
reels.transcript: I'm Alex Bellini. I'm an explorer. In 2017 I crossed the biggest glacier in Europe, the Vatnaj√∂kull, in Iceland. But it's then I was afraid of losing my life. But it's then I got close. In 2025, eight years later, I felt the need to go back to those places. To look for answers and maybe to go beyond.
